39118642.review:
An investigation and research game that places you in the shoes of a paramilitary operative. Features live events, many, many multi-part missions, and a lot more.
Pros:
Sound design is good.
Lots of content
Decent community
Difficult puzzles.
Active developers. They run a 24/7 discord channel with staff or reps online to help players. should they need a nudge.
Augmented reality. From research outside of the game (a must) to live events where you can apply to take part in real-world events with the community, it's a very nice and immersive experience.

Cons:
Sometimes the community can be negative and discouraging, especially during the live missions.
Some of the voice acting can be odd. The Alone In The Dark Web expansion had some very lackluster and seemingly forced VA. Most of the others were great.

This is a buy if you like to put your mind to the test.

38843059.review:
Calling Black Watchmen a "game" does not properly describe the environment or the experience. At groundstate, the experience comprises solving a series of challenges (not properly puzzles) to determine some piece of information so as to proceed to the next challenge (Missions).

You must spend time with Google and Wikipedia researching historical (true) subjects. The developers provide the URLs for a few online utilities to accomplish some tasks, I usually used Wolfram Alpha or Mathematica. Among my other tools includes: GIMP, Tiddlywiki (I suggest the Leaf plugin), Google Earth (a bit tricky to use), and a notebook. You NEED scratch paper, especilly during cipher decodes.

Consider BW more as analyst training, rather similar to Orwell.

I spent Christmas solving the Whitechapel missions, and now do one or two missions a night.

Warning: you may encounter the situation where you input a result only to receive a failure alert. The interface seems >>>VERY<<<< sensitive to case and whitespace. An expected answer of "lake of blood" may fail to match on " lake of blood", "lake of blood ", "Lake of blood", "lake of Blood", etc. When you hit such a problem, you can often solve it by cutting and pasting from whatever document you found containing the string.

38815593.review:
Unlike anything else I've ever played. Using real-world information to solve a delightfully bizarre mystery has me addicted! So far I've pieced together corrupted images, rummaged through discarded receipts, sent e-mails from my personal account, and researched actual historic events. It's not easy, but when finally get an answer after scouring the internet and piecing together clues bit-by-bit, it feels amazing.

At times it all felt a little too real, and had me quite uneasy! Absolutely recommend giving this a look. You won't find another game like it.

37865099.review:
I really, really love nonconventional games and The Black Watchmen is as nonconventional as it gets. It is a game, yet it feels like you've managed to stumble into some weird, dark, mysterious corner of the internet. When solving these (glorious! devious! awe-inspiring!) puzzles I frequently wondered if this was real life or part of the game? I spent hours on some church website, searching through the church committee minutes for clues to one of the puzzles and to this day I still don't know wheter that website was real life or part of the game. I love that! 

The Black Watchmen had me observing buildings on Google Earth Street View, scouring through Facebook, closely studying user profiles (set up by the game), contacting companies, reading pages of reports and documents, all to uncover great mysteries and it was absolutely thrilling. It especially shines as a co-op experience, as my girlfriend and I played it through Skype, devising strategies and discussing clues. This went on for most of the day after the game, where we were still sending eachother links, articles from Wikipedia and other interesting background information. All to climb up in the ranks of the mystifying Black Watchmen. 

To anyone saying gaming as a medium is oversaturated and devoid of any new impulses I say: go play The Black Watchmen and you will see that there are still so many exciting new ideas popping up left and right. Granted, it takes a certain kind of player to enjoy an experience like this but I for one am so happy with games like The Black Watchmen and Ahnayro. So support  these guys! They deserve it.

36170212.review:
I want to start by saying that TBW was gifted to me by a friend and I was somewhat sceptical, despite being very much interested in what the game offers: suffice to say [i]I loved it[/i].

I want to dissipate one thing I've seen Europeans do: bash the game because it's not localized for every region.
I am currently playing from Italy and I have encountered no problems when it comes to displaying the files on my browser, neither when it comes to making calculations or going on with medical terms. Google is your friend and if you know how to use it, you also know how to isolate results in only the language you need. I'm not a magus that knows every little medicla term or knows 100% of everything. I'm a human that knows how to search on Google for my answers.

This said, I also want to address the issue of the lag: I've played a lot of games that run on Unity - while most of them were laggy, the fact that TBW utilizes the interface just to give you a small debrief of the mission in form of a video, an overview of how you're doing and what you have unlocked and a handy dandy chat to communicate with more seasoned players for help, helps a lot to keep the lag under control. I've never had any problem and I still don't suffer any of them to date.

The Immersion is absolutely incredible and, if I only lived much closer to the developers' zone, I would've definitely signed up for a more [i]immediate[/i] involvement with the game's mechanics. Alas, I'm restricted to being only able to play up until code red. 

All, in all, at the end of S1, I binge-bought everything (plus their game Ahnaryo), just to be able to experience more of it. Looking DEFINITELY forward to "In the Deep Dark Web".

36036060.review:
It is time for me to review this game.  At over 52 hours in game it is safe to say I enjoyed this.

The Black Watchmen is an awesome puzzle game.  Reading through the reviews I was wondering what I could add to from the positive or address from the negative because I absolutely love this game.  It certainly takes a page from the online games Godtower and notpr0n and if you are a fan of either of those then this is the game for you.

Yes, there is a level you can't skip and you have to wait until the office is closed and this did affect me, seeing as I had a time difference to deal with, too but the game is based in reality and you are pretty much role playing an intelligence agent.  So if you can deal with this for ONE level out of the lot then you will be just grand.

So, should you buy this game?

YES, if you:

- Enjoy using your intelligence to look for lateral solutions to puzzles 
- Are prepared to spend a day or two not advancing in the game at all and basically just hunting for a break in your current level
- If you enjoy reading and learning new things
- Can understand that some solutions have multiple solutions and whilst the one that you found might not make any sense, don't get angry because you probably went the long way around to get there
- Are looking for that whoosh of euphoria when you solve insanely hard puzzles

NO, if you:

- Are incapable of the above
- Dislike puzzles
- Lack patience
- Need 'a game' (Black Watchmen is barely more than a UI and you will spend a large amount of time on Google and other webpages rather than in the actual game)
- If you can't avoid or help yourself from just looking up the walkthrough for every puzzle

Here are some other things that I would like to add.

1.  When you push the button to take you online, it is annoying to be taken directly to the Black Watchmen Forum page rather than say, Google.  An option to set your own homepage from that button would be nice.

2.  Bear in mind this is largely a community game and you (and I) were very late to this party.  The forums have all the answers for the game in one neat and tidy thread. If you are buying this game in 2017 or later, my advice would be to get a friend to buy it as well and play it together and work as a team to get the solutions.  Stay off the forums and youtube walkthroughs.  

Edit:  A friend and I made a podcast about this game.  SPOILER ALERT!  If you haven't played it yet then stay away.  If you have finished it or just don't care then go here....leave a comment if you liked the review or hated it.  

https://soundcloud.com/user-31623090/episode-1-filling-the-gaps-the-black-watchmen

[b]IT IS NOT FOR YOU[/b]

LOL, I hope you enjoy the game as much as I do!

35406116.review:
It's not a game. It's a way of life.

Jokes aside, though, it's a fun puzzle game that takes immersion to the next level. Rather than having a main character following a story with cutscenes, the developers chose websites as their medium. YOU'RE the main character and the moment you start playing the game, the world around you becomes the in-game universe.

The game is simple: they give you a task and you figure out a solution to complete that task. That means opening up Google, facebook; heck I used Microsoft Paint to decode a cipher. The 'puzzle' aspect is being able to meaningfully jump from one website to the next without going for 'Red Herrings' (look it up in the dictionary). In the later levels this becomes very challenging for one person. It will take a literal team of players of different skill sets to complete the hardest puzzles.

What is the game about? Well, this is an ARG (Alternate Reality Game) where they will take real world scenarios and have you solve puzzles to advance your career as a private security contractor. 

What sets this game apart from every other game, puzzle or otherwise is that many of its NPC interactions can take place in the real world. This means NPC's are actual people. Missions take place in your hometown. If you agree to their disclosure, they will send men after you in the real world (no joke). Keep in mind, though, this only happens when you sign the agreement, pay the fee and you're in a location where they can pull it off. If you're the average player like myself, you probably take more pleasure in watching/helping remotely. 

You're going to have to pinch yourself hard to get out of the game. Really. It will distort your reality and ruin you from the inside. Where do you think I'm typing this review from? The comfort of my own home? Pah! I'm currently locked up for espionage and high treason.

The game gets a 10/10. One of the greatest puzzle games of our time. It's unfortunate nobody knows about it.

35050617.review:
Every game I play has a story to it, and this is no different.

My story begins as your average Overwatch player, right after the announcement of their first new hero, Ana. Those who have played Overwatch will likely know where this story is going, because immideatley after her announcement, an ARG was launched which teased the SECOND new hero in Overwatch, namely Sombra. Dowm the rabbit hole I went when I discovered Game Detectives. I became obssessed with these online puzzle, or ARGs as they're commonly called and when Alice and Smith teamed up with Game Detectives to make ARGs, I discoverd The Black Watchmen.

6 months after my discovery, I finally bought the game. Though I am only 9 missions into the actual game, I'm already more than excited to see what secrets this game holds for me as far as the IRL interactions go. I've spoken directly with game developers, and interacted with TBW community a bit, and I have to say that Alice and Smith as a company has a gold standard when it comes to community interactions.

That being said, I asked the question "How does this game even have a negative review?" and that's when it all made sense. This game is most definetly NOT for everyone, but if it is, it will satisfy you to the core of your puzzle solving experience. If you're not already playing TBW, and you love paranormal/puzzle games or ARGs, I highly suggest playing this.

34305142.review:
I just finished the first season. Took me about 12 hours for the 25 missions (Bonus missions not yet unlocked, bonus information will be my next step)
The "The Black Watchmen is not like any other game on steam" is justified. It is like a pen&paper RPG come reality with you as a character. 
The first missions are only tutorial missions, so you don't get immersed into the world of TBW. But then it gets started. With every mission, every puzzle you solve, you get deeper into the occult. You learn stuff about medicine and other things, you never thought you'd need or want to know. Sometimes the puzzles can give you quite a headache. There are some hints in TBW forums that might or might not help you. In some puzzles they didn't help me at all and so I found my own way. And that's what the game is about: find your own way. Even though some ppl have problems with some answers (they want one answer and only one sometimes) I never had that problem. Mostly it's just the first name or so you come up with. Sometimes you need to think rather less than too much.

The voice acting and the material you get is awesome. You get pictures, text documents, shrederred documents, blurred or partly destroyed pictures, voice recordings (even voice editing is required at some point), and even non-english language. Be it some demonic language or french, well might as well be the same. 

You won't have it all ez pz, but all puzzles are solvable. Sometimes you just need to let it rest for some time and then look at the clues and your notes again, and then with a snap you realize how you overlooked an important thing. If you are into puzzles and want to immerse into such a darker image of our world, here ya go. This is the game for you!

In the end this game will fuck up your browser history, and you will see some ppl and institutions in another light. You will learn something and might even improve your IQ. 
But there is still one problem: I am not 100% sure that this is not some training tool to filter out the best analytics and recruit them for some kind of real Black Watchmen. So beware of being to good maybe, you might find a world you never wanted to find.

34116923.review:
Il y a beaucoup de choses à dire sur ce jeu et personnellement je l'adore. Néanmoins, il faut avouer qu'il est très particulier et beaucoup de précautions sont à prendre si vous comptez l'acheter, quand bien même il ne coûte pas très cher. C'est pourquoi je vais d'abord vous présenter ce qui pourrait vous faire fuir avant de m'intéresser un peu plus à The Black Watchmen !

Sachez déjà que vous avez intérêt à avoir un solide niveau en anglais. VRAIMENT. Pas tant au niveau de l'interface du jeu en elle-même et la présentation des missions, qui sont compréhensibles. Mais plutôt pour affronter les centaines d'obscurs fichiers PDF, thèses, vieux rapports, extraits de grimoires, etc... qui pourraient s'avérer indispensables à la réalisation de vos objectifs.

D'autre part, c'est un jeu où vous (et éventuellement les autres joueurs) êtes le/la principal-e responsable de votre plaisir. Je ne parle pas de masturbation hein, je dis juste que si vous n'avez pas envie de vous prendre pour un analyste/agent secret qui débute, ce n'est même pas la peine de jouer. C'est vous qui allez fouiner pendant des heures les recoins d'internet pour résoudre des puzzles esotériques sur des feuilles de papier qui joncheront le sol de votre pièce, alors vous avez intérêt à jouer le jeu ! Si vous voulez rester vous même, ou vous améliorer, ou retourner en enfance, je ne sais pas... ne jouez pas à ce jeu. Si vous voulez devenir un-e Black Watch(wo)men, jouez-y. Vous comprenez où je veux en venir ? :D

TBW demande une implication intellectuelle, temporelle et émotionnelle. SI vous ne pouvez pas (pas assez de "fenêtre de temps de jeu" pour cause de boulot, famille, etc) ou n'avez pas envie de le faire, passez votre chemin.

Bon si vous êtes encore là, vous vous demandez peut-être ce qu'il y a de positif dans mon évaluation... j'y viens !

Plutôt que de vous faire une fiche technique du jeu, je vais vous livrer deux ou trois anecdotes sur le thème
"Depuis que je joue à TBW" :

- On peut trouver dans ma liste de marque-pages des choses aussi diverses que : le repertoire des cabines téléphoniques aux Etats-Unis ; les détails de fabrication et de crackage des cartes à code ; un monitoring mondial des homicides ; le dictionnaire énochien ; des données d'observation météo sur la foudre ; des outils de décryptage ; une liste de poisons et de leurs antidotes ; la carte des cables sous-marin ; la liste des symbôles occultes.

Ca a quand même plus de gueule que Facebook, Lemonde et Youtube non ?

- Tous mes comptes divers et variés sont sécurisés avec des mots de passe comprenant 256 caractères, le tout très facilement et sans prise de tête, alors que je pensais que ce serait le contraire. J'ai appris à crypter mes fichiers sur mon ordinateur, facilement également.

- Je lance chaque nouvelle mission en sachant pertinement que je vais ruminer, rager, pleurer, déchirer, gribouiller, raturer, hurler, fracasser (etc, etc...) devant des puzzles a priori insolubles, mais que par moi même ou grace à l'aide d'autres agents je triompherai de l'énigme et me sentirais ULTRA BADASS. J'insiste sur ce point : rarement dans un jeu vidéo j'ai pu ressentir à quel point la réussite dans une mission est quelque chose de gratifiant.

Je suis navré pour celles et ceux qui attendaient une évaluation "type", mais justement, TBW n'est pas un jeu "type". Quoique presque confidentiel, il est néanmoins connecté à d'autres jeux vidéo (Perfect World, d'autres titres d'Alice & Smith également) d'une manière ou d'une autre, ce qui est déjà intéressant en soi. La communauté autour du jeu est petite, mais soudée est extrêmement réactive en cas de galère d'un agent. N'espérez pas trop qu'on vous lâche la réponse en vous caressant le tralala pour autant hein, nous ne sommes que quelques centaines à avoir triomphé de toutes les embûches... de toute manière, les adeptes de la facilité n'ont vraiment rien à faire chez les Black Watchmen !

Chaque mission, chaque saison, chaque opération spéciale, chaque mission créée par un-e joueur-se est connectée à un thème plus ou moins "confidentiel", ce qui donne une atmosphère très particulière au jeu et permet également - pour peu que l'on soit quelqu'un d'alerte de curieux - d'étendre le champ de nos recherches et de connaissances, pour le plaisir de le faire.

Il y a encore de nombreux petits à côtés et autres fonctionnalités, que je préfère ne pas vous dévoiler. "Je vous en ai déjà trop dit". Quoiqu'il en soit, c'est ça passe ou ça casse : ou vous adorez et nous rejoignez au sein de la Division. Ou vous retournez à votre vie antérieure. Mais si vous franchissez le pas, sachez que vous ne serez plus jamais la même personne. 

Question d'honnêteté.

34116249.review:
There needs to be a sideways thumb for this game.  For everything The Black Watchmen does right - the ciphers, the research, the obscene amount of notes you feel like taking for every mission to track your thoughts - the game also has some pretty glaring flaws.

That flaw is being vague as hell.  I won't give any spoilers here, but some missions ask you for a specific thing and give you a clue that has NOTHING to so - seemingly so - with what you're after.  It's so abstract that it becomes impossible to even get your foot into the door of your solution.  It's like this: what is 2+2 if you have ten pancakes on the roof of a flying saucer.  Using this solution, plug it into the amount of times the sun spins around and calcuate how many pennies Jimmy has if five fish are swimming in a bowl.

You ARE given clues in some missions and some of the research and abstract thinking is good.  You'll probably have to reach out to forums to give you a little nudge in the right direction or find out what others did to get to their solution.  It sucks but that's what this game's curse is.  Sometimes their intel just isn't enough to get you started.  

Beyond the vagueness of the game, it's not bad.  I expected it to be better but we'll see if my image of the game changes the more I play it.

6/10: would try to solve puzzles again without enough information.

GONGRATULATIONS ALICE & SMITH!!!

"The Black Watchmen"  is my first ARG Game ever and I didn't know what to expect  when I bought it.
A few hours later, I realized one thing. This is one of the BEST GAMES EVER. PERIOD. 
If you are interested and new to ARG like me, this is the best time to give it a try, before the new upcoming season and the live events! In that way you can have the time to learn and to get the main idea of how this type of games work.

33203016.developer_response:
Allo!

Je suis bien navré que tu n'ai pas aimé mon jeu et ça me fera plaisir de t'aider à avoir un remboursement. Avais-tu essayé la démo avant d'acheter le jeu? Il y avait les 3 premières missions dedans pour éviter de mauvaise surprises.

J'ai fait beaucoup d'effort pour avertir les gens que ce n'est pas un jeu pour tout le monde. Certains adores le style de puzzle ARG (enquête en ligne, recherche et wiki) alors que d'autres déteste.

Au niveau des DLC je ne suis pas d'accord par contre. On a fait un jeu de base avec prêt de 70 puzzles. Quand j'ai fait la saison 2, c'était une nouvelle série complète de 60+ puzzle. Chaque saison fut fait avec les joueurs: ce sont eux qui ont déterminé en live l'histoire. Ce qui est vendu sur steam c'est le résultat d'une saison active. Idem pour les micro-DLC, ce n'est pas comme si j'avais fait un jeu et après retiré du contenu pour faire des DLC.

Contact-moi via adoyon@aliceandsmith.com.

31504936.review: Hello. Are you bored of your all-too-normal life? Looking for something truly special to be a part of? You're in the right place. Buy the game, undergo your training, and become an official agent of [b]The Black Watchmen[/b]. It'll be one of the most rewarding decisions you could possibly make. Once you take the first steps in your path you'll find a welcoming, helpful, and largely active community of devoted agents. Looking to immerse yourself even deeper? Eelevate your clearance level in the upcoming season, you won't regret it. [i]Become a part of something bigger than yourself.[/i] [b]Join the agency today.[/b]

31339996.review:
The Black Watchmen is a puzzle game that grabs the fourth wall and promptly throttles it into the stratosphere. Each mystery is solved by scouring the web for a solution to a task, assisted by your favorite search engine and internet browser. As a member of The Black Watchmen, you must uncover various top secret investigations away from public scrutiny as you scour the internet in search of a solution to a lead given to you by the agency. The game is quite hard to do solo thanks to the large variety of skills and knowledge required to play, but many people on the TBW forums have supplied new agents with helpful hints that can bring their investigation to a close.

The developers allow you to choose your desired level of immersion; there are no days off for Black Watchmen agents! You start off on the basic Red Clearance level, which is nice and easy for casual players - when you aren't running the client, your experience ends. Upgrade to Orange Clearance by providing your phone number, and you may receive a voicemail, call or text from an important character with information you can share with the other agents working on the same case with you. Upgrade to Yellow by including your mailing address and you might receive important information in your mailbox. At Green Clearance you are required to undergo a medical examination and sign a waiver. If you're chosen by the other agents (and the game dev), your task would include traveling to select destinations and interacting with or avoiding NPCs as you perform an investigation with the help of the other agents. Black Clearance is the most immersive experience in the entire game, and likely involves serious roleplaying.

The game itself is fun on Red Clearance; it takes a bit of researching and wit, though. The game can be difficult at times, especially since the solution isn't always obvious to you at first. This game definitely isn't meant to be binged either, and I imagine the sense of reward from solving a puzzle would be much greater when a whole group works together to solve a puzzle they're all stumped on than it is working through all these puzzles alone or by researching other players' findings and reading their hints. Even so, this ARG is still quite a lot of fun, and twists many interesting narratives for people to follow.

I tend to get frustrated easily if I can't find an answer to a puzzle immediately, but the clearance levels have locked my interest and the upcoming season has me excited for what's to come. If you aren't quite sure about this type of game, give the demo a shot. The game gets much harder past the training levels, but you'll also be doing cooler stuff like manipulating NPCs into giving you access codes or helping a squad place bugs in a medical clinic to eavesdrop important phone conversations.

If you like the mysterious nature of conspiracy theories but hate the destructive nature they tend to have, you'll love this game. If you want a unique mystery puzzle experience based on research, you'll like this game. If you liked roleplaying detective games as a kid, you'll love this game. If you wish you were James Bond, you.... might not. There's not much "action" unless you get to the much higher clearance levels, but those are honestly unlikely to happen to you and buying the game solely for the high clearance scenarios will leave you dissatisfied.

Overall, this game comes highly recommended from me. The aesthetics of this game, the unrivaled sense of immersion, the active community and the gameplay all create a very enjoyably frustrating experience for me - much like a difficult Sudoku or Crossword puzzle.

MUSIC: 6/10. It's FANTASTIC, but there isn't enough variety. The moody, downtempo soundtrack may end up inducing drowsiness by the end of your first Season.
GAMEPLAY: 8/10. Co-operating with other players to solve puzzles grants you the opportunity to roleplay with many different people from around the world and create strong friendships based on the common interest of ARGs and the occult. Some investigation methods can be a bit finicky and purposely time consuming though, which might make some bingeplayers like myself a bit disappointed. [Live events have not been considered in this review as I've not participated in one yet.]
VISUALS: 9/10. The aesthetic this game presents is second to none in its genre. The design toes the line between campy and immersive, but is definitely pleasant to look at either way.

TOTAL: 9/10. The overall experience I've had this game has been overwhelmingly positive. I will update this review after the conclusion of the next Live Event.

30731907.review:
[h1]Résumé[/h1]
Si vous aimez passer du temps à faire des recherches, lire des pages et des pages en anglais et que [b]vous avez un bon niveau de compréhension orale en anglais[/b], ce jeu est pour vous. Sinon, ne l'achetez pas, vous allez vous ennuyer ou vous risquez d'être facilement frustré par les premières énigmes.

À part pour la compéhension orale en anglais, l'énigme 3 de la démo représente bien le reste du jeu, donc n'hésitez pas à la faire si vous avez le moindre doute. À noter tout de même, la question est posée de façon un peu étrange dans la démo et la réponse peut donc sembler plus difficile à trouver qu'elle ne devrait l'être pour une énigme de tuto.



[h1]Évaluation complète[/h1]
The Black Watchmen est un (très bon) Alternate Reality Game, qui vous fera envoyer (et recevoir) des mails à des PNJ, rechercher des informations sur Internet, explorer de vrais sites webs de fausses compagnies, éplucher les comptes sur réseaux sociaux de fausses personnes, et vous forcera à prendre souvent une bonne heure pour réfléchir à chaque énigme. Pour vous faire une idée, la démo est un passage obligé. Son 3eme niveau correspond vraiment à ce que vous allez faire plus tard dans le jeu complet (en version légèrement plus complexe, à vrai dire, puisque la question à laquelle il faut répondre n'est pas aussi claire que son équivalent dans le vrai jeu).

Généralement, vous pouvez vous contenter d'ouvrir le jeu uniquement pour récupérer les informations dont vous avez besoin, prendre quelques notes sur les indices qui vous sont donnés ou même juste les enregistrer sur votre ordinateur, noter la question à laquelle vous devez répondre, et quitter le jeu pour faire vos recherches tranquillement/aller vivre votre vie et ne revenir à l'étude des documents que quand vous avez un moment. The Black Watchmen est très prenant, et trouver la réponse à une énigme après de longues recherches et une trentaine d'onglets ouverts en même temps sur votre navigateur a un côté super satisfaisant. La qualité des documents fournis avec le jeu ne gâche d'ailleurs rien, et étudier des blueprints ou des enregistrements de conversation de cette qualité va faire plaisir à l'enfant-agent secret qui sommeille en vous.


En revanche, je ne [b]recommande pas[/b] ce jeu si vous n'avez pas un (très ?) bon niveau d'anglais. The Black Watchmen nécessite un vocabulaire relativement étendu (il vaut mieux être capable de faire l'ensemble des recherches directement en anglais) [b][u]ainsi qu'un bon niveau de compréhension orale[/u][/b]. Si vous avez du mal à comprendre une conversation en anglais, vous risquez de vous retrouver incapable de résoudre par vous même des énigmes impliquant l'étude de fichiers audios, ce qui serait juste frustrant.

28665125.review:
[b] 一个非常棒的硬核ARG解密游戏。非要来个评分的话，是11/10吧	[/b]（笑）

这个游戏涉及到相当多的信息。游戏本体中会提供图片、音频、网址之类的资料，让玩家通过现实中的浏览器去查看图片、PDF、网页，并通过这些来寻找所需的信息以破解谜题。

这些信息其中有些是虚构——兴许也是真实的，但于我而言确实难以确认其真实性，姑且认为是虚构吧——有些则是真实的，例如前几个mission中有关于[spoiler] AEC在US本土婴儿身上做的核辐射实验	[/spoiler]（←涉嫌谜题剧透）等。也有很多地方涉及密码学——虽然的的确确非常地，初级入门——如果不使用官方提供的convertion tools，那么好歹也能稍稍学一些皮毛吧（笑）

[spoiler] 不过这样的硬核解密游戏对于很大一部分人来说应该算是比较无趣的，购买之前思考一下自己是否会厌烦从各种图片、PDF里找寻信息以及在google里搜个不停吧。	[/spoiler]

需要提醒的是，由于游戏只有英文，而且部分音频没有字幕，任务中大部分资料也都需要查找英文资料，因此英文苦手的玩家最好不要入手这个游戏。

另外，记得挂vpn，不然游戏中的视频根本加载不出来，播放视频只会是一片空白，然后立即显示出“replay”和“close”两个选项。

游戏本体中大约有30个mission，按照我目前3小时5个mission的效率来看（我记录在案的时间中至少有1个多小时是刚开始玩时在等待我的辣鸡VPN加载视频），完成所有的mission怎么说也要20小时+，毕竟它的难度似乎是递进的。

在游戏中绑定手机号和邮箱等联系方式似乎会在日常生活中时不时收到即时紧急任务，看介绍好像还有通过现实世界中的快递（or包裹）等来完成mission的，这一设定大大增强了虚拟与现实的交互，想来一定是十分有趣的——然而，身处国内，似乎不大能支持这种mission。

steam上有三个The Black Watchmen的DLC。而在制作方为这个游戏专门建立的论坛上，玩家可以彼此交流在mission中搜集到的信息以破解谜题，也可以互相分享自制的mission。自制mission有四五十个，本体通关以后玩这些应该也能玩挺久。

另外，游戏的文字walkthrough似乎全网都找不到，并且官方和大部分玩家也都比较推荐去论坛中交流彼此搜集到的信息，但假如你真的完成不了当前的mission，那么[spoiler] 挂上VPN去Youtube看看就是一个很棒的选择了（笑）	[/spoiler]

还有！游戏界面非常酷！BGM也很带感！

综上所述，这是一个可玩性相当高的硬核解密ARG，通关所需时间绝对不短，在游戏中还能学到许多新的知识，winter sale的最低价24元真的十分超值。

最后，[spoiler] Welcome to the agency recruit!	[/spoiler]

Agent Cheyenne

The Black Watchmen. Simply one of the best Alternate Reality Games on the market, with an active team of people that come together and manage to solve nearly impossible missions set by the Black Watchmen dev team. The amount of hours that you could potentially put into 1 level is unreal, but can also provide for a boring experience after a while.

However, saying that, the topics that The Black Watchmen pull up are far from boring as you'll be studying the occult, dark magic and secrets that people don't want you to know about.

The Black Watchmen puts you in the shoes of a member of "a paramilitary group dedicated to protecting the public from dangerous phenomena beyond human understanding". Even with how long you or I spend on the internet each day, the things that you find from lurking in the dark corners like this game makes you do is interesting, and to see the kind of things people believe in and write about is entertaining.

The Black Watchmen isn't just about researching however. The dev team creates realistic but fake documents, websites and people for you to look into and complete missions around. There are huge arrays  of missions ranging from find out about a tornado, looking into supplies recieved by a company, secret occult clubs and murders.

27583973.review: It is difficult to write a sufficiently descriptive review for The Black Watchmen without revealing too much about the game. In short, it's the puzzle aspect from The Secret World without the MMO combat of the latter. The puzzles are very clever and often require outside research into esoteric and obscure topics. Essentially a big part of the game takes place outside the actual client, which is why after a couple of weeks playing The Black Watchmen exclusively, I still only have 7 hours logged in the game. The game is broken into missions, which are thematically linked and tie together into a compelling narrative. Moreover, all of the Alice & Smith games actually take place in the same universe as the aforementioned The Secret World so there are references to events from Funcom’s MMO in the later missions. I enjoyed The Black Watchmen tremendously; it is quite unique and certainly worth trying. You may even learn some interesting, disturbing or just entertaining facts about the world.

25835710.review:
I love ARG's.  So imagine my utter disappointment, when I realised I have just missed over a year of what is arguably the finest ARG I have ever played?

The Black Watchmen somehow slipped under my all-seeing radar, which is incredibly sad.  Sad because I have missed out on joining what will no doubt be a superb global effort, of thousands of players all staying up unreasonable hours, just because they are not quite able to understand just what that picture is supposed to represent, and why wings matter,

The game is literally centered around the real world.  You use a central tool to receive puzzles and enter answers, and through where clues and information are given out - but the rest is found 'out there', in the real world.  Professionally designed websites (that don't immediately stand out as obviously fake) are used, as well as authentic places around the world, are all used to give you that sense of PRESENCE that is sorely missing from other attempted ARGs.

It isn't without minor fault - the occasional typo, but really nothing that you wouldn't see in real websites I assure you!  

I've yet to move up the agent rankings.  You start off as a Red agent, meaning world interaction is limited to just you initiating email based contact.  Later, you can optionally apply for other grades of agent interaction, from email only, to full on creepy - phonecalls in the middle of the night, strange letters in the post...  I am absolutely in for that, and will give the required info as soon as I am able!

What I have yet to experience, and I cannot WAIT to do so, is the live events.  As you might expect, you collaborate with global agents via IRC, forums, the usual, in order to solve puzzles in real time.  Apparently, one agent is picked to experience this in a full-on 'reality show' - I know nothing about this other than what I've read, so I suggest you, dear reader, do the same.  I, sadly will never be 'picked' as I am not physically able, which is utterly sad, but nevertheless, I loook forward to the day I can help solve such events.

Being a puzzle game, based around the internet, you are inevitably going to come across spoilers.  However, in saying that, I have solved every single puzzle without 'bumping into' any obvious answers, which is nothing short of unbelievable.  There are solutions out there, in the exellent Blackwatch Forums, which should be visited daily.  The answers to particularly difficult puzzles can be found, but only after  you've worked your way though a lot of excellent spoiler hints.  This makes you feel like less of a cheater, and more as what you would have experienced had you been around at the time the community was solving it, just as you are now.  

The hints are very well done, asking YOU questions rather than just simply giving you the solution.  It makes you feel a lot better about seeking help, because you know you were not the only one a bit lost on how to continue - only to find the right track with just a smallest of nudges.  (There was one particularly nasty puzzle which I will not spoil, and I needed every clue they gave - and even then I STILL couldnt' immediately solve it - I really had to put the clues together).

In closing, you may initially buy The Black Watchmen, and feel like you didn't get a lot for you cash.  But, if you like puzzles, if you like something a little different from the normal, if you understand stressing over a number is fun, and solving a puzzle gives a certain amount of euphoria, you absolutely MUST buy this game.

25158187.review:
This review is for season 1 only. Other parts will be reviewed separately.

HOT DAMN. Those of you who've played The Secret World or heard about it from others know the investigation missions were the real standout -- the kind of insane games artistry that could have (and should have) supported their own game and not a clunky MMO. Well that's what we have here. The Secret World's investigation mission team gives you a slightly spun-off world of high-tech and dark magical conspiracy to investigate. 

Crack ciphers, do real-world research, and use all sorts of real-world puzzle solving tools and methods to order nuclear contraband, investigate ancient secret societies, and stave off extinction-level events of paranormal origin. By and large, puzzles are ground in what makes *sense*. You need someone's password? You don't solve a matchstick puzzle. You phish their password with a real email! Need to place snipers for your strike team? Consult IRL maps outside the game application and find where you have sight lines. And you'll probably have to learn a bit about demonology, Chinese astrology, and nuclear reactors.

The Black Watchmen offer up some crazy mindbenders, and while most puzzles feel very fair, be prepared to give them some time. If you're not comfortable attacking some puzzles from different angles for a few hours, it may not be for you. When you've really hit a wall, the game's social system and forums (where people are VERY cool about nudging you without ruining the mystery) will help you through.

24185750.review:
I'm really struggling with this one. Is it even a game? In the strictest sense, yes. But you may find it much more frustrating that some of the old hardcore 80s games that no one could get passed the 1st level.

I won;t go into what this game is about, as there are a load of reviews that say what this is.

Its not a game in the strictest terms, Its more of an intellectual excercise. A role playing game where you take on the role of an agent.

Some missing are fun to do, others are down right ridiculous. For example, (possible spoiler alert) i just did a mission where it offered you a template to use, You have to research someone, fill in the blanks and then send an email to social engineer a way in. the issue is that if you were not 100% gramatically correct, you couldn;t get past it. And sending the same email over and over trying to get it right kinda breaks the immersion, as it simply wouldn;t work like that ITL. The rwecipient would have become a little suspicious.

I'm finding more and more that i'm heavily relying on looking at spoilers in the forums trying to find out what on earth i'm supposed to be looking for this time..

Apparently the IRC and other help factors are still active, but i have never gotten a response on any of them.


If you are looking for a game that you can jump straight in, this is not for you. If you are looking for a game that is pick up and play, this game is not for you.

If you are looking for something that will challenge your intellectual and creative pants off., this game may well be for you.

I strongly suggest trying the demo from their main website before buying the full game, But remember, if you find the demo hard, you won;t get very far in this game. The missions can be infuriating, sending you off with little idea what you are supposed to be looking for. and beyong the first few missions, the difficulty becomes greater exponentially.

If you want to try something new, give this a go. I got this so my wife and i could try and work together solving the missions. Sadly the UI was too small to have on the TV, so that idea went down the pan after a couple of missions.

Is this a good game and would i recommend it? Thats a tough one, as it would be a different answer depending on whom i spoke to.

The idea is great, the missions leave a little a little to the imagination, and sometimes are truly baffling.

I'm going to give this a thumbs up, purely that its a great concept. However personally, i'm starting to get annoyed with having to check forums for every other mission just to give me an idea of where to start. let alone how to get the correct answer.

21297718.review:
Unprofessional and petty developers who basically banned me from their forums for posting a negative review of their game on steam (can't post new threads or even make posts in existing threads anymore), even though i've never broken any rules or behaved badly, normally i wouldn't give two hoots about this, except to play this game you are expected to frequent the games forums and irc.

They also decided to withhold all of my irl interactions that i was supposed to receive (that i paid for!!!!) during season 1 and 2 (i bought this on day 1 of season 1), they instead decided to operate this game like a pyramid scheme, where only the most active 10 or so players will receive any irl interactions outside of the simple phone number confirmation call and address confirmation letter, requiring you to spend 8+ hrs a day hanging around in a dead irc, waiting for a live mission to start, for weeks/months before being classed as one of these "first tier" members, if ever.

When live missions do come around (only 5 per season and once they over you can never play them again) the community as a whole are very self centered and mainly bothered about who was the first to work out a puzzle and tell everyone else the answer, most of them unfortunately see this as "team work", some of the mods of the forums/irc are also very obnoxious and like to shout others down to have their idea listened to over others.

Client missions suffer hugely from poor role play, purposefully confusing and misleading mission briefs (from an organisation your supposed to work for, who need your expert help...) and even just plain poor puzzles.

Personally i would advise all to stay away from these unprofessional and petty devs, but, if you're still interested as puzzle games are your thing then wait until a season is about £5 or less before purchasing, at this price point you may find some value if you're heavily in to googling random information.

New seasons are WAY overpriced (yes you have to buy them!) as you are paying for the "first tier" players to receive phone calls and basic letters through the post for live missions, and unless you were here since the start of season 1 (I was and even I havn't received any), its pretty much guaranteed you will not be a first tier player.

Also, you do not even need to own the current season or even the game to "take part" in the live missions, you can simply create an account on the games forums for free, waste your days in their dead irc waiting for a live mission to start and then follow along.

TL/DR - A forum based alternate reality game (that you normally find for free) thats been shoe-horned into a steam game and had its price massively inflated with the promise of IRL interactions you simply wont receive, all ran by a seemingly petty and unprofessional group of devs.

21002564.review:
Well, I came into this expecting something along the lines of 'In Memoriam' (Missing, if you're in the US).
Sort of a follow-the-breadcrumbs style of game using real-world browsers.
And it sort of is.
You're playing as an agent of this undercover agency designed to protect against supernatural (I think) threats.
You get hints and clues, and it's really up to you as to how you go about deciphering them.

So, the good stuf first.
I love the idea. This whole blending of real-world and game is right up my alley.

But that's about it for the good stuff.
On the con-side however.......
The objectives themselves for each chapter are very vague. Add to that, a lot of the clues are bewilderingly worded, so you spend a lot of time either researching things that you don't have to because the answer the game is looking for is right in front of you.
Or, you spend a few hours doing a hunt-the-hidden-answer, as you try to figure out which of the bits of information you have will actually allow you to progress.
If you've ever played some of the old text-based adventure games where you had to find the correct word for the game to trigger correctly, you have an understanding of what is going on in this game.
It doesn't exactly help that the difficulty-level is all over the place.
You jump from dead-easy into a maze of strangely worded questions that absolutely requires prior knowledge to figure out.

And of course, with these types of games comes an inherent shelf-life.
If you happen to buy this game a year from now, is there any guarantee that any of the embedded web-sites needed are still around?

It's a very neat concept, it's just not very well executed.

EDIT: Are you f*cking kidding me?
A puzzle-hint involving a FaceBook account??
Okay, first of all, there is no 'clear link' between the Rosenberg Clinic and Superterram Life Sciences.
One does neurological research, and the other is a body farm.
One is in Montreal, the other in Texas.
There are no documents, mails, telephone-taps or anything else that would make this company any more interesting than any of the others.
The only real link is that it's the only company-name that actually pops up in the search-engines.
That's not deduction, that's just mechanical grinding until you eliminate suspects.
And besides, are you really telling me that we can find a higly classified document re. medical experiments on the intranet, but apart from that we only have a vague browser-history to go on?
That is honestly just bad writing.

Even if I were willing to forgive that, using FB as a part of your game is.....
Well, let me put it this way; if having a FB account is required for completing this game (which it is), I would strongly suggest that you put it on the list of game-requirements, along with processor, GPU and all that.
Had I known it was a pre-requisite, I wouldn't have touched this game with a proverbial ten-foot pole.
And before you say "Just use a pseudonym and create a FB account".....
That would violate the ToS of FB, and is technically illegal.

First game I ever bought where I have seriously contemplated going for a refund.
Oh well, too late now.

20458672.review:
The Black Watchmen (TBW) game really hits the mark as a great Alternate Reality Game (ARG): in TBW you play the role of a paranormal investigation agent, fighting demons, witches and black cults around the world.

The TBW agency is powerful and well connected. While playing, you have the chance to exploit many different personal skills, as you work in front of your computer screen (using the game client or accessing the internet as well). In that case, code-breaking knowledge, social media and social engineering skills will be your assets! Many training missions are provided for your preparation as well, and the players' community is very helpful if you are stuck on a single player mission.

Furthermore, you can play with other agents using the game chat assets: you might even have the chance to actually go in field! Depending on your chosen clearance level in the agency, in Real Life you might be asked to analyse objects or document you receive by mail, or to go out in your town delivering documents or, in some cases, to meet actual NPCs, especially in the occasion of the game Live Events that involve collaboration of all TBW agents for a single mission that might go on for some days.
TBW is a great game, I really think that it is worthwhile to give it a try. You will be surprised!

20458415.review:
What can I say.

I've only had this game a few weeks but I've been sucked into the addicting and immersive world of this game. I was a little reluctant to buy this game at first because I wasn't sure if I wanted to be a part of the ARG aspect of it. The great thing about TBW is that you don't have to do any ARG stuff if you don't want. Even the live missions can be completed without any of the extra stuff. However, now that I've realized how awesome the game is though, I've started to get into the ARG aspect of the game. 

Basically there are 5 levels of immersion. 

Red: The lowest level of immersion. The only thing required for red is an email.

Orange: This level is a bit more immersive. You have to register your phone number and will sometimes get phone calls/voicemails for live missions.

Yellow: Yellow is the highest level conventionally available. To be a yellow agent you must submit your location and will receive mail and sometimes have to do things in your area. 

Green: To be a green agent you must submit a full medical report and do a ton of real world stuff. Only 1 of 8 people are selected for green each season.

Black: Classified Info

As you can see, the game gives you a lot of different options to choose from.

Now to the actual game. The game is very addicting and challenging enough to keep you wanting more. You investigate everything from illegal testing to cults to mutants to the apocalypse. The game does a great job of making you feel like you're somewhere you're not supposed to be. 

Not only is the game and immersion great, but the community is one of the most welcoming communities I've ever been a part of. You can go to the forums at forums.blackwatchmen.com and the IRC at  https://kiwiirc.com/client/irc.blackwatchmen.com/division66
The vets will always be glad to help if you're stuck on a mission. 

Anyway, I love this game. It's addicting, fun, immersive, and has a great community. 

10/10

TL;DR great game, great community, buy it now.

20458108.review:
This game... And what a game it is. 

>>AGENT: Ellis
>>CLEARANCE: Yellow
>>LIVE MISSIONS: 1

>>START REVIEW:

Have you ever looked into the history of games, and stumbled upon something called " ilovebees.com "?

It was part of a promotional campaign for Halo 2, that appeared for 2 seconds In one of its ads for E3 (or something like E3) that lead people to investigate details about the site, eventually finding coordinates to payphones around america, and a time for each payphone. 

Everyone appeared on time to each and every payphone on time, despite one of them being in the middle of a hurricaine at the time.

That, was one of the first ARG's, and is probably the most famous one to have existed.

An "ARG" is an "Alternate Reality Game". And ARG's usually involve investigating websites, history, places, and cryptology to gain details on a fictional story.

Baisically Larping for the digital age.

However, the difference between standard ARG's and The Black Watchmen, is that ARG's are normally used for promoting a product, and they usually end at some point. 

While the former is certainly the case (TBW is part of The Secret World MMORPG's lore), This game's selling point it that its missions don't go away after the ARG is over, but as far as I know (S1 Mission 16), these missions don't involve anything in the real world, and you don't need to go anywhere.

In Live missions on the other hand, you need to interact with the community via irc chats and their forum to solve specific events (e.g. Using google to Hunt down 5 german buisnessmen for sleeper agents to assasinate, because they know too much), and do tasks in the real world that're related to the event.

However, you can also choose how involved you are with the game's world by choosing what clearance you want to be. 

>>RED CLEARANCE: Nothing irl will happen to you. You can play the game through the client and interact with the                                                 community, and that's about it.

>>ORANGE CLEARANCE: You may get phone calls by providing your telephone number.

>>YELLOW CLEARANCE: You may get phone calls and packages, and you may have to interact with actors playing a specific role.

>>GREEN CLEARANCE: The most known amount you can get involved. You have to be voted for it, and supply a medical exam for this. Missions will involve you, and they may take more than a day to finish.

>>BLACK CLEARANCE: This has been hung over our heads for a while. We don't know what it is.

In conclusion, I'd reccomend this game, as it has some very interesting puzzles based around finding codes based around books, the bible, and historical figures, which might end in you learning about something interesting. 

If you have any form of paranoia, I'd [b]STRONGLY[/b] suggest researching this game, or asking someone that knows about this game if it's suitable for you.

>>END REVIEW

19401660.review:
The Black Watchmen é um PARG sendo o [u]primeiro de sua categoria[/u]. Logo, é um jogo completamente diferente de qualquer um que você já tenha jogado e não pode ser comparado a nenhum outro.

[h1]O que é um PARG?[/h1]
PARG ou PERMANENT ALTERNATE REALITY GAME, de acordo com o [url=http://www.blackwatchmen.com/whats-a-parg/]site oficial[/url], é um jogo que mistura o mundo real com o mundo do jogo utilizando acontecimentos e locais reais. O que o diferencia de um ARG é o fato de poder ser jogado sem a necessidade de ter acompanhado a história desde o primeiro dia assim como os ARGs tradicionais além de não ser restrito a campanhas pequenas. Os jogadores colaboram entre si para achar pistas, resolver puzzles e completar missões e é aí que entra a questão do multiplayer.

[h1]O Multiplayer[/h1]
Você deve ter notado que o jogo está marcado como um MMO, mas isso [b]não[/b] deve ser entendido como um jogo estilo World of Warcraft onde você escolhe o servidor, cria seu personagem e se encontra em uma cidade com um monte de jogadores. Muito pelo contrário, o jogo apesar de possuir uma funcionalidade de multiplayer onde um jogador pede ajuda e outros (no máximo 3 pessoas) se juntam a ele para ajudar, é um recurso pouco usado e então o que realmente o torna um MMO é a presença de uma vasta comunidade em [url=http://forums.blackwatchmen.com/index.php]fóruns[/url] e redes sociais em que os jogadores colaboram entre si para completar as missões de forma mais abrangente e não limitada a 4 pessoas como citado anteriormente.

[h1]O jogo[/h1]
Chega de enrolar e vamos ao que interessa! Bem, o jogo funciona da seguinte maneira você recebe uma missão como "identifique a empresa que realizou tal coisa" (claro que não é uma missão qualquer, há uma história que vai se desenvolvendo ao longo do game) e junto você recebe alguma informação sendo assim você analisa a informação e descobre a resposta. Essas informações podem ser uma imagem, um pdf, um audio, um texto ou até mesmo um site. É importante notar que as vezes é preciso pesquisar na internet com base nessas informações para chegar à resposta (posso até dizer que 75% do jogo está na internet e não na steam). Para entender melhor a dinâmica do jogo recomendo que você baixe a demo, com ela você poderá ter uma boa noção do que se trata o game. Não assista vídeos pois podem conter spoilers da história ou te dar as respostas estragando toda a diversão.

[h1]Contras[/h1]
Primeiramente, é impossível ter o aproveitamento 100% do jogo sem morar nos Estados Unidos pois é possivel cadastrar seu endereço e telefone e assim eventualmente a equipe do jogo pode interagir com você para te dar missões e entre outros, mas não se preocupe isso é o de menos; Você precisa ter um bom inglês para jogar já que absolutamente tudo está em inglês e em muitas situações o Google Tradutor não vai resolver (não é exatamente um contra mas pode pesar na experiência); O jogo é dividido em temporadas assim como o The Walking Dead da Telltale, logo para continuar jogando você vai precisar comprar a segunda temporada em diante.

Eu pessoalmente amei esse jogo, é uma história envolvente e possui elementos incríveis que vão te surpreendendo a cada missão. Sou um dos poucos brasileiros que jogam ele então sinta-se a vontade para conversar comigo caso tenha alguma dúvida :D

19049615.review:
This game is probably one of my favourites of all time. It can get frustrating at times, but I love how difficult it can be - it makes it extra rewarding when you work out the problem!

It seemed a tad expensive when I first saw it, but it really appealed to me - and god-damn it's worth it! It really is worth the punt if it sounds like your kind of game. The user interface is simple, but clean and well polished.

It's a mix of puzzles, cipher/code breaking, hacking (things like email accounts) and researching (digging for information online). The story is great, if a little far-fetched/fantastical. I love how it ties in with the real world - I've even had real-life mail come through with a mission. The developers seem to be very dedicated to the game, adding many new events, live missions, and extra community sandbox missions.

I've been off on so many tangents whilst researching to complete the missions. You can spend hours looking into the completely wrong thing, but you learn so much in the process. A lot of the story is based on medicine and occultism, and it is interesting to learn about these subjects. 

I really hope Season 2 is just as good and addictive. I think if all of us who enjoy the game can get the word out there, and get more players in the community, much bigger things will happen, including many more live events.

Thankyou, Alice & Smith, for creating this game! It truly is one-of-a-kind, and in my eyes, a great success.

18291578.review:
Please excuse the poorly written review, this is possibly my first go at a serious review. :^)

[h1]So what is 'The Black Watchmen' ?[/h1]
[b]The Black Watchmen[/b] is an ARG, where you (or your character) can become an active agent of the organisation of the same name. The ARG itself includes puzzle solving, cryptography and online research.
No real life skills are needed however if you have experience with cryptography and if your Google game is on-par, you will enjoy the game. If you are unsure, you can always try downloading the demo before you decide whether you'd like to purchase the game.

Bear in mind at this point, you can buy the first season which includes a total of 25 missions as stated in other reviews. Currently sandbox missions are being added, which means user-submitted missions can be played. Once Season 2 is out, you can purchase the missions that come with it.

[h1]Tell me more about this game[/h1]
While you play the game, you will need to research topics and look online for answers. If you give up easily or don't feel like using wikis and Google is something you want to do, perhaps this game isn't for you and you should look elsewhere. Of course, if you're just having issues with the game you can always look for help in-game as well as in the Black Watchmen official IRC channel (linked in their official website) as well as in the official TBW forums - the community is great and spoiler-free! Furthermore, you can either collaborate with others who are on the same mission as you or seek attention from folks who have already passed the same.

[h1]What about the staff?[/h1]
From my brief, however positive experiences I can say the staff members are excellent, supportive and exceptionally well-mannered (I tip my digital hat off to Santiak and and Anashel, who were more than happy to provide me with all of the assistance and additional information I needed regarding the game).

[h1]So is it worth it?[/h1]
I have personally enjoyed the game so far. I'm currently on Mission 7, I've been blazing through missions so far and Mission 7 stumped me (Mike is to blame for this).
Should you buy it? Yes, absolutely. It has been so far a great experience for my first ever ARG. Looking forward to finishing up all of my missions and proceeding into Season 2 once it's released. :-)

I rate this game conspiracy/10.

18206080.review:
Now that the first “season” of the game has ended and Early Access is over, I think I can give a more wholesome review of this game. 

Firstly, I wrote a guide to navigating this game. If you want to know what an ARG is, look at the first part: 

http://steamcommunity.com/id/riningear/recommended/349220

Tl;dr it's a puzzle game with some online-RP/LARP aspects. 

Let me make this clear right now: No. It’s not for everyone. I really do respect that. Especially with the “Live Missions” aspect -- some of the stuff is time-sensitive, and it can be a lot to keep up with. That’s part of an Alternate Reality Game like this. And not everyone wants to opt into receiving phone calls and/or packages. That’s really fine, but I understand it can leave some players feeling just a bit underwhelmed by the content because of their lack of choice to do so. (If you opt out, you’re not useless -- you can help those players figure out the puzzles. It really does help.) 

If you want to get a feel for what's going on, download the demo, chat with the community in the IRC (there's a guide to that in the guide I linked), and poke around the game's forums to check out the gameplay that's happened. 

With that said, if you do choose to play this game, there’s a lot of considerations to be made. 

Someone I’m friends with at school saw me playing this and asked: “Why Steam?” I think that’s an important question. This is really the first major, recent attempt at a business model for an Alternate Reality Game. ARGs are usually constructed by third parties as promotions for existing or upcoming products -- Ingress, for example, has an Alternate-Reality platform to support its Augmented-Reality platform. In fact, The Black Watchmen is the direct product of The Secret World’s ARG promotions, run by the same company. 

With that said, as someone who joined in during the Kickstarter, reaching out to a broader audience and trying to pull people into a niche from the mainstream definitely is a challenge. I think that’s where I saw a bit of a struggle with the devs, especially with “live” missions. It’s easy to come from a background of appealing to more hardcore ARG players and later have issues trying to ease into something more palatable. 

That’s where we get into something that could have easily made or broken this game -- the devs. I literally cannot have enough praise for them. While many ARGs attempt not to break the fourth wall in helping its players, there’s a mutual understanding between the devs and the players that this is a new exploration of the genre, a real attempt to make something bigger out of what’s been a niche genre. So there’s been a lot of conversation between the players and devs, and I really appreciate that, as both a player and an “investor” (I mean, it was only $25, but I didn’t have much at the time…). 

It really showed in the final “live” mission. All the complaints and criticisms led up to a very involved, very well-thought-out kind of experience that roped in a lot of players. I had my own personal approach to it, but I had no time to manage everyone, and so they did it on their own to great success. 

I guess that’s something else that’s kept me in: the community. A strong backbone to an ARG is its community, and this community has always been really warm and welcoming to new players. I had to squeeze in back during a much more difficult mission during the Kickstarter, but now it’s certainly opened up nicely. It’s something you have to get involved in to believe. 

For those of you wondering about the gameplay and puzzles… unless you’re a savant of some kind, you definitely need help on some of these missions. But that’s fine. In fact, the devs encourage it. And these missions are immersive and exciting, especially towards the end, and even if I didn’t have live missions available, the $35 I would have spent (soon $15 for this season after the sale/month ends) would have likely been worth it to more intense puzzle fans. (Though in a market of $10 puzzle games… eh.) 

But some of these puzzles that dig deep into the oddest parts of your knowledge and trivia, and your Google search skills. It’s pretty cool. I definitely recommend at least working through the puzzles if you want to try “something else.” Once you get to know that little noise effect from a successful answer, it'll be your best friend and the warmest feeling in the world. 

The client’s odd and bulky in some parts and we’re trying to exchange feedback about it. A lot of it's left over from the beta versions. But you won't be using it that much anyway, given the game involved a lot of real-world research. 

[b]Summary:[b] Great puzzles, great people. Definitely invest if you want to be a part of something new and exciting. But it’s not for everyone -- try the demo, check the IRC, get a feel for it. 

Just don’t be rude if it isn’t for you. A lot of the negative reviews are often because people are uncomfortable about the game’s aspects. Don’t fall into that trap -- figure it out for yourself.

18147335.review:
[h1]ALRIGHT, TIME TO CLEAR A FEW THINGS UP[/h1]

[olist]
[*]This game is [b]NOT[/b] subscription-based! Think of it more like The Walking Dead series, where you pay for a season whenever it comes out. You can play any seasons you own indefinitely.
[*]This game [b]WILL[/b] take over your life. Like the slogan in the old ARG Majestic from EA: "It plays [b]YOU[/b]" Will clarify later.
[*]The game on Steam is only 25% of the actual game. [b]It takes place in real-life, on websites created specifically for the game, and on social media.[/b]
[/olist]
[quote=Santiak]It's an astounding epiphany to realize just how helpful every thought process can be; overanalysis, stray thoughts, daydreaming, incoherent thought produced by sleep-deprivation, they all have a place of import in the TBW Agents toolbox.[/quote]

Before I start with anything, I would like to make this clear: This game will be one of the most unique experiences you will ever have, and it will [b]take over your life[/b] (I am saying this again for emphasis). They will make calls to you, they will send you packages, etc... If they need to contact you, they will, be it social media, e-mail, phone calls, you name it.

[h1]BUT, BEFORE YOU BACK UP, SAYING "EHH, THIS SEEMS SHADY", KEEP THIS IN MIND:[/h1]

You absolutely [b]DO NOT[/b] have to give them any info. All these things are [u]completely optional[/u] and will not work against you if you decide to not do so. They only act to increase the immersion of the game. 

You have [b]FOUR[/b] types of Agent Levels:
[list]
[*][b]RED[/b] is the lowest level of immersion. Interactions with red level agents will take place through the mission hub and by email.
[*][b]ORANGE[/b] is more intense: voicemails, references to your area of operation - an aerial view of a nearby intersection, for instance - live streams from your hometown, and even live calls to, say, a phone booth at the end of your street.
[*][b]YELLOW[/b] is the highest level of immersion conventionally available. It involves phone calls (which might come at any time of day), suspicious packages sent by mail, and real world interactions with NPCs.
[*][b]GREEN[/b] is only open to the bravest agents. If you are selected to experience the deepest level of immersion, you must submit a full medical exam and sign a personal injury waiver - just in case any harm should come to you during your mission. Green level is not for the faint of heart, but if selected, you will remember the experience for the rest of your life.
[/list]

Let me actually clarify some more on the Green Agent level. This is not one for the faint of heart. This is THE most immersion you will get out of this game. Packages in the mail, phone calls, [b]a black van sitting outside your doorstep[/b], really anything! Make sure you have plenty of time if you are going to do this, though. It makes you a mission-imperative agent, and the success of missions will depend on your cooperation.
[quote=Nikel][12:03:12] <@nikel> "Isn't this somekind of illuminati witchcraft simulator?"[/quote]
This game covers tons of different topics. Currently, we went over these subjects:
[list]
[*]Cryptography
[*]Social engineering tactics
[*]Human trafficking
[*]Human experimentation
[*]Occult magicks
[*]Photo reconstruction
[*]Wiretapping
[*]Goetic demons
[*]Alchemy
[*]Summoning rituals
[*]Stopping the [b]END OF THE FREAKING WORLD[/b]
[*]How to screw around on the IRC channel instead of actually finish the missions! :D
[/list]

We just reached the end of Season 1, and I am super excited for Season 2!

[h1]The live events are definitely one of the best parts of this game.[/h1]

Live Missions are the thing that really make this game that much more immersive. Instead of just adding a new mission to the client, they will send either a phone call to a select few agents, or an e-mail message (usually both). It is then up to the community to do the following:
[list]
[*]Figure out clues that are left in the small amount of info provided
[*]Communicate effectively, figuring out solutions that would otherwise be impossible to do alone
[*]Update Dispatch daily with their progress, providing them with information, pictures, or whatever they need at that time
[*]Do things not just in-game, but in real life! [spoiler](For example, we all had to find an iron statue, and draw a sacred sigil, aiding in the fight against some crazy cultists)[/spoiler]
[*]Meet up with other agents out in the field, or work together with non-player characters.
[/list]

What I listed here is only the tip of the iceberg here, folks. In Season 2, it is bound to get even more crazy and more immersive than ever before.

[h1]SO, TO SUMMARIZE, WOULD I RECOMMEND THIS GAME?[/h1]
[b]ABSOLUTELY![/b]

This is definitely one of the most unique gaming experiences I have ever been a part of, and I am glad to have this game in my library.

Do you like games that constantly break the norms, and keep you on your toes?

Then this game is for you.

Do you love it when games constantly keep things fresh and interesting, without too much handholding on new missions?

Then this game is for you.

Here are some words from our IRC group:

[quote=AgentFellowship]"Got into TBW late in the season and I STILL had a blast. The Steam client is sleek and makes you feel like James Bond hacking into enemy databases. The live mission I played was incredibly fun due to the amazing community dedicated to making the game special.[/quote]

[quote=Zekh]"When I close my eyes, I see ciphers"[/quote]

[quote=dylanamite]"If you're looking for a one-way ticket to a pysch ward, you're in luck! Just start searching for the hidden Info Pieces and you'll soon find yourself in a straitjacket"[/quote] Just for your info, the Puzzle Pieces are the hard-mode part of the missions. Hidden secondary answers to the missions you already did.

[quote=MediumSizedDipper]"My favorite thing about The Black Watchmen so far is the way that the live events and real-world missions build such a sense of camraderie. It's really easy to forget (or ignore) the fact that everyone else is playing a game, just like you."[/quote]

[h1]ANYWAY, I hope you consider adding this game to your collection. It is one of the best experiences I have ever been a part of, and I hope to see you soon in-game![/h1]

An extremely interesting game for those of you who like to research and play a game in the real world. It's a Permanent Alternate Reality game - meaning that to advance in the game, you have to do things that require you to do it on the internet, or even, if you're brave, in real life. You have to use your brain, social engineering and research. You learn many things on the way - it's extremely fun, I just planned a Mission Impossible infiltration yesterday.

 It's also very spooky since it includes secret organizations such as the Knights Templar or Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn. You sometimes have to infiltrate and decode the things sent to them/by them - and it somehow manages to make you feel as if you were actually doing it - extremely realistic.

 If you do decide to buy the game, never look at the things you see in the game generally. They all often require thinking outside of the box and you have to brainstorm to find out what they mean. Tell me if you decide to play - I've finished the game all by myself in twelve hours. I'll help you out.

 If you buy it now until the end of the September, you'll get Season Two for free. I highly recommend it.

EDIT1: The game doesn't end when you finish the missions it throws at you. I just received emails with even more things to decode and research - it's going to be a long-term relationship between me and this game. If you finish it like me, look at your email - there's bound to be something there from Division 66 that requires you and your skills.

I chanced upon The Black Watchmen through Steam's Recommendations and for once, I have to give credit where it's due: thank you Steam. I've always envisioned this to be what gaming in the future to be like, where it's partially crowd/out-sourcing with a twist of community spirit and the opportunity to learn new and exciting things.

Others who have reviewed this have gotten it right too, this "game" isn't like the rest of them on the catalogue, this is a beautiful fusion of passion and intelligence, brought to life through missions and real-world references. This reminded me slightly of The Secret World without the typical MMORPG element of button-mashing.

(And a little research actually pointed that very obvious part out to me: this was a initiative headed by Human Equation for Funcom, the developers of The Secret World)

If you enjoyed the puzzle-solving elements in TSW like I did, you'd no doubt be a big fan of this. The puzzles are challenging but not unsolvable, the voice-acting and script are superb, and the concept behind this is just mind-blowing.

Thank you for making this game!

17731863.review:
I am a fan of this game already. But i will try and keep this review un-biased as i can...

I think first you need to understand something about this game. This is not just a puzzle game. I can imagine the developers had a hard time deciding what they would describe this as, genre wise. And how to market a game on Steam that is more than a computer game.

Because thats what you have here. Something that breaks down the fourth wall. Not break through, it gets rid of it. you step off the stage as a person, as you. Or at least you if you were in a different reality. Its a game that expects you to put some real work into it. By using real life resources such as search engines, and even websites generated for the game. real websites. Not websites shown by some in-game UI. A real website that you access through your browser of choice.
This game asks you bring skills to it or at least learn them.
There is even an aspect (which is optional. See below) that requires you to get out of your chair and head into the world. 

Lets look at that last aspect for a moment. As it is probably the only one i can see being somewhat controversial. There is an aspect to this game that seeks to turn it into a LARP (Live Action Role-Play) like experience. Understand that it is optional. But it is where this becomes a hobby in itself rather than just a game.
You may, if you so wish, provide your phone/mobile/cell number. And if you wish to go one step further, your address. By doing this you are immersing yourself in the game world. You can receive phone calls giving you clues to new or existing mysteries. Or a package in the mail that holds some object that is part of a current mystery or is something new. All in the style of an X-files like conspiracy theory narrative.

And this game does have a narrative of sorts. As i stated it is a little like a LARP. There is an on-going player driven story. What you and others as players do in the game world has consequence. It affects what happens next.

Community is a very big part of this game. Whether you go the full immersion route or not. You all play as a group working together towards a common goal.         

I feel this is a game that needs to be experienced to truly appreciate what it is. I just found a new hobby. And all I did was buy an Early Access game. I or anyone else can try and describe this until blue in the face. But I don’t think it can be described. Words don’t do this game justice. 

Anyway, this review is long enough.

Look, the small answer to whether you should get this is simple:
If you read the description, watched the trailers, and found you were intrigued. I say give it a shot. At worst you will play through the first episode, get some entertainment through the puzzles and then move on. At best; you will be hooked. And you will participate in something you most likely have never experienced that is a work of genius. Something that, as a gamer, you will have fond memories of in the future. 

I hope to see you in-game.
