16852776.review:
**** Full Disclosure: I'm a volunteer Moderator on the official forums; however I'm not paid in any way, shape or form. ****

EDIT: Since I posted this review, I have been hired by Alice & Smith as PR/Community Manager. Therefore, I will no longer update this review as long as I hold that position.
Also; to make room for this update, I removed the "Updated" list at the end of this review.

[h1]Content:[/h1]
While the amount of content seems limited, it is worth making a huge note that the Content of any ARG is not found primarily in what you are presented with - in this case, what you see when you start the EXE file - it is the secrets you can find based on that initial presentation.

Currently there are, officially, 6 In-client missions available, in addition to 1 Live-event that's been concluded.
The unofficial tally, however, is much more than that; there are hidden solutions for in-client missions, logins on related webpages to uncover, files in archives to discover, and so on.

[i]Edit:[/i] There are, in fact, still numerous ongoing investigations based on those first missions, that the community has either yet to solve, or have just recently solved - reports of the current missions being "done and over with in a matter of hours", mainly come from people who never thought to look deeper.

To name but a few of the yet unsolved puzzles as of the time of this edit, the community is still working on:

- Finding all hidden solutions to 3 of the 6 current In-client missions.
- Finding the password(s) for websites and communication channels found based on the in-client missions.
- Finding hidden Archive entries.
- Finding out how they relate to what we know.
- Finding out what the meaning is behind the information found in the logins that have been cracked, so to speak, such as images, odd product information, and the like.
- Solving the significance of a series of cryptic phonecalls to some agents; finding where and/or what they lead to.
- Participating in the discussion of what our next step should be in preparation for the next Live-Event.
- And tieing up loose ends left over from the Live-Event, such as an unsolved cipher that the community managed to by-pass.


Most of these come from the In-Client missions, with a subset being left over from the Live-Event.
With the exception of the hidden mission solutions, none of these routes were "indicated" to the players; they were discovered by the players themselves. 

You can see the potential amount of gametime if you compare the time of this update, with the time TBW was launched on Steam, and the amount of unsolved missions and loose ends.



[h1]Live-Events[/h1]
Live-Events are not "show-and-tell" via IRC; IRC is merely the place where most Agents brainstorm during Live Missions, while they work on the clues and puzzles that come up in the course of those Live Events. 
Meanwhile the "official updates" during those events can come in the shape of either emails, phonecalls, video or audio files discovered, dead- or live-drops intercepted by players in real-world locations, or Dispatch (Devs) or NPCs (Actors) joining IRC in order to directly interact with all Agents, to name but a few methods that have been used previously.

[i]Edit:[/i] Some misconception exists surrounding the Live Events as being the "Bread and butter" content. 
While they certainly demand a lot of resources to do - actors and writers willing to interact with Agents at potentially any location in the world, and around the clock - missing them is by no means tantamount to missing out on the majority of the available content.

As hinted at above, there is [i]a lot more[/i] to be found in the In-Client content, and by no means is the majority of content found in the Live-Events, neither in terms of gametime nor money. Nor vice versa.


[h1]Pricing:[/h1]
First and foremost; it is not subscription based. It is Episodic. The distinction is important because;

- "Subscription" carries with it a connotation that one pays a monthly fee, in return for access to a game, regardless of whether or not new content is added. (e.g. MMOs)
- "Episodic", on the other hand, means one pays for new content, knowing roughly the expected amount of content to be gained. (e.g. Episodic Adventure Games)


[i]Edit:[/i] As mentioned above, In-client and Live-events make up the content, so it is also pertinent to tackle both of these seperately, in terms of what costs they each involve:


[u]Live-Events include[/u]:
- Actors to pose as NPCs, be it at an arranged meeting spot, as people who call or otherwise contact players, and in some cases do so well outside regular hours for their timezone.
- Writers who "flow" with the actions of the community, ready (and able) to adapt if the community decides something unexpected.
- Arranging dead- or live-drops, which includes actors, items, and research.
- Production of videos, audio, photos, and so on.
- Production of clues, websites, logins, and so on and so forth.


[u]In-Client content include[/u]
- Production of video, audio, photos, and so on. Including hiring actors/voiceactors for recurring roles.
- Production of missions, hidden missions, archive documents, hidden files, and so on, which must all include a coherent and believable narrative, that is at the same time both "supernatural" in feel, but also very much grounded in fact.
- Setting up professionally made websites that look and feel as the "real-deal", including customer service phone numbers, email, location, and so on - basically so however much players research, they can never be entirely sure it's not an actual place.
- Arranging phone-calls or physical objects to be sent out in some cases, or responses to Agents contacting "Dispatch" (Devs/NPCs), either as part of the interaction with the abovementioned websites, or as part of a more elaborate "hint" function than the typical 'press this button'.


[u]Free-to-Play Live-Events?[/u]
Finally, another rising misconception is that Live-Events are things that people who haven't bought the game can interact with "for free".

Anyone participating outside of the client will not have the framing - by way of the overarching narrative - to follow the "what" and "why" of what happens in a Live-Event, and the main component of ARGs is exactly that narrative.

Likewise, alerts to Live-events are given out to Agents (i.e. players who bought the game), either via email or the Situation Room (Red level), phone (Orange), or mail (Yellow).
As such, anyone who is not actively partaking in the community or did not buy the game, is many times more likely to miss out on the live-events, as they simply do not get an early warning.

In addition, the first steps of Live-Events have thus far involved the Situation Room, and may well involve entering information into the Client or reacting to updates in the Sitaution Room as the event unfolds.

Finally, you will arguably not be eligible for intercepting a live- or dead-drop if Dispatch (Devs) can not confirm your involvement with them - so you'll also miss out on that potential interaction with the game.


[h1]In Summary:[/h1]
What you get out of The Black Watchmen is highly dependent on what you put in:

- If you only start up the client, do the presented missions, and leave it at that, you won't get your moneys worth, nor will you enjoy any ARG.

- If, however, you go beyond the client, look closer at the things you were presented with in the client, wonder what connections there might be, poke at the websites you were introduced to, look at the sourcecode of sites you were pointed to, try to find hidden files in archives, see the correlation between two disparate documents, manipulate images and audio files you find, discuss your thoughts with other agents on IRC, google docs, forums, voice chat, and so on, you get your moneys worth. 
If not to say a whole lot more than you bargained for.

16820947.review:
Common misconceptions that people seem to have about this game:

1) 'This game requires you to put in personal information in order to play'

The only thing this game requires is your email. You CAN, but DO NOT HAVE TO, put in your phone number, and address. This puts you in a pool of people who can, but will not necessarily, be contacted by the game with special clues. 

2) 'The devs are screwing people by asking for $35 up front. I mean, the game is only in early access, they only have 6 "missions" actually finished!'

This game works somewhat like a TV series or a Telltale Games game. The content is episodic in nature. 3-4 missions are released every 2 weeks. The "early access" bit is misleading, as all content for the game is pretty much finished, save for the pieces of the plot that the players can impact. The game will be off early access after the first two weeks, assuming that there are no technical problems with the game. As for the price, the developers put the price at $35 based on the ideal of paying $1/1 hour that you can get out of the game. Of course, this is only an estimate, and those gifted with a high intelligence may find that they are completing the game faster than this. This price will drop as the season progresses, because some of the content, such as the live missions, will no longer be avaliable. If you only want to play this game for the puzzles, without any of the community content, I suggest waiting for the price to drop. 

3) ‘Full enjoyment of this game can be achieved without too much effort.’

This is a part of the game some people dislike. The truth of the matter is that this game will require a lot of attention to get the full experience out of it. The 19 missions that the game will have on steam can be completed at your own pace, but other content such as the live missions MUST BE DONE in real time. In other words, if you aren’t keeping up to date with the community, you’ll probably miss out on stuff. One of the major selling points of this game is the community that surrounds it. If you don’t like this, that’s ok. It just means this game probably isn’t for you. 

TL;DR: You should probably read up on everything that you should expect, and will be expected of you, before buying this game. It is a unique experience that many other games on Steam cannot provide, but that experience may not be for everyone. Be sure you know what you’re getting into.

EDIT 1: The developers of the game just announced 5 more missions for the first season at no additional cost to those who have and will buy the game. For those with doubts as to the motivations of the developers, this should be a good sign.

EDIT 2: Season 2 announced. WOOOO!!!!

16802355.review:
Dieses Spiel ist wirklich schwer zu beschreiben. Besonders da es das erste seiner Art ist. Es ist immer die Rede von „augmentierter Realität“ und ihr fragt euch vermutlich genauso wie ich (bevor ich das Spiel gekauft habe) was darunter in diesem Fall zu verstehen ist. Eigentlich ganz einfach, das Spiel verschmilzt die Realität mit Inhalten aus dem Spiel. Grausame Experimente die in der Realität passiert sind werden in die Dichte Story nahtlos eingewoben und verschmelzen zu dem Erlebnis das ihr aus diesem Spiel gewinnt. Ihr übernehmt in diesem Spiel allerdings „nur“ die Rolle eines „Schreibtischhengstes“. Man fühlt sich praktisch wie ein NSA Mitarbeiter und übernimmt die Detektivarbeit nur vor seinem eigenem Computer. Doch das Ganze trägt nur weiter dazu bei, das man sich so fühlt als würde man zu der virtuellen Agency gehören. Man sinkt ein in diese Welt die voller Geheimnisse, die mit unserer realen Welt verschmilzt. Das Spiel ist also rein gar nichts für labile Persönlichkeiten die an so etwas wie Chemtrails glauben.

Dieses Spiel ist voller Rätsel und geistigen Herausforderungen und interessanten sozialen Kontakten mit denen man sich gemeinsam über die Teils (alleine unmöglichen) Rätsel den Kopf zu zerbrechen und erfüllt gleichzeitig einen Bildungsauftrag indem es über vieles das real ist aufklärt. 

Ich empfehle jedoch ein gutes englisches Vokabular mitzubringen das auf einem soliden B2 Niveau basiert, da dieses theoretische Konstrukt komplett auf Englisch basiert. Wer also schon Probleme hat mit der Sprache wird sich mit den Teils spitzfindigen Rätseln schwer tun, die oftmals einiges an Fachwissen im Bereich Naturwissenschaften abverlangt und man ohne das entsprechende Vokabular erst einmal eine Übersetzungsrunde starten muss.

Für jeden der sich also damit anfreunden kann und auf theoretische Rätsel und komplexe Inhalte steht kann ich dieses Spiel uneingeschränkt empfehlen. Mir bereitet es sehr viel Spaß und ich mag den Weg den es einschlägt.

16758845.review:
About 8 years ago, I got an e-mail. From "A Friend". She was seeking help. There was a clue in the e-mail, the clue led to a website, a website that had an image on it.  The image had a clue in it, it unlocked in to a forum. What the hell, I thought. There was a sole thread. You've made it. 

As other strangers arrived we got to discussing what the hell was going on, who was this person, why are they seeking our help? What do these images mean? Why us? Why have we been targetted? Over the coming days the buzz of activities heightened, the sense of urgency to solve this mystery was on. We all worked together deciphering images, clues, morse code, sonar radars until we finally uncovered the truth.  It was a viral ARG for The Secret World announcement.

ARGs are all about following clues, deciphering images, looking for meaning in things, researching real world events, connecting dots, going down rabbit holes and coming up short, stepping back and realising that you might be overthinking things.  The Black Watchmen does all of that and more. Like others, I was aprehensive about giving out my personal details, but I haven't disclosed one piece of personal information and have had a blast with the first 6 missions so far.  The community is one of the friendliest online communities I have come in to contact with, ever. :)

If you have any doubts whatsoever about getting enjoyment out of this at Red Clearance level, then put your mind at ease. You can still join in with the discussions on IRC, you can bounce theories off one another in the Forums, you can work together outside of the client to further investigate leads from the client.  Perhaps in time you will feel more comfortable with the idea of giving out your details and decide to become more involved.  It is entirely up to you how involved you want to be, I guess the more you put in to it, the more you get out of the experience.

This ARG uses the real world as the surface with you becoming part of a secret organization who deals with those events outside the realm of the police. You can have packages sent to you and even be called upon to go to locations in your area to help in the live events. The potential is huge for this game. The devs have been hands on with the community, quick to answer questions and keep everyone excited about what is on the other side of the rabbit hole. 

Some are complaining about the price as it does include the first season (roughly 3 months). This includes not just the game itself, but live events and secret missions. I do feel that you will get your money's worth IF this type of game appeals to you. The more of yourself you are willing to put into it, the more you will get from it.

Greetings!

The exact same amount of content is available to everyone, regardless of what "Clearance level" they opt in for; the same number of missions, puzzles, and objectives.

The "Clearance level" system is entirely optional. It is only there to allow players who choose to take advantage of the option to gain an increase in the level of verisimilitude of the game, allowing them the chance to receive updates for certain live-events via phone rather than via the client, IRC, or our forums, for example.

16718252.review:
A Weekend With The Black Watchmen ARG

The world is overflowing with mysteries and conspiracy; some are visible to all, but others are less obvious, hidden beneath a layer of secrecy, lies and the occult. If you go deep enough down the rabbit hole you are bound to discover some disturbing things – things almost too plausible to be true. Blood rituals, human sacrifice and experimentation are mainstays of the silver screen, there’s no way that they could be taking place beneath our very noses, or could they? There are agents worldwide investigating these disturbing reports and this weekend I joined them to get to the bottom of some shadowy people and their dealings. This is how I became a member of The Black Watchmen.

I initially mistook The Black Watchmen as just a game, but it is much more than that. I am now part of a secret reconnaissance cell partaking in undercover investigations. My basic training involved learning to crack codes – binary, hexadecimal and rot13 enciphered messages – a cinch given my degree in computer science, but things soon became more difficult. My fellow agents and I were tasked with investigating the disappearance of an antique collector – and that’s when things took a decidedly more sinister turn. The case files we were given, drafted by the first agent on the scene, consisted of nothing but seemingly innocuous images of books, dolls, crucifixes and bottles. The keen-eyed among us were able to identify a rot13 enciphered code in one of the images, which we were then able to decipher manually. The code pointed towards a pastebin link with details of an antique script called “Folio 13″, the kind a collector would love to have in their collection, but how did it tie in with his disappearance?

A Google search for “folio 13″ and “Cipher MMS” lead me down a rabbit hole of religion, conspiracy, secret societies and the occult. I was suddenly in over my head, reading up on ancient Jewish sects and Pope John Paul’s teachings – certainly nothing that could be attributed to the disappearance. I was over thinking things, going way too deep and missing an answer that was right in front of me. The organisation that penned the document wanted it back and was willing to go to any lengths to get it.

As the case was solved I gave myself a pat on the back and put my feet up, but my respite didn’t last long. The agency had heard word that a clinic tied to rumours of human experimentation had reopened its doors and I had been asked to investigate its staff members for any signs of illegal activity. By cross-referencing each staff member’s employment history I was soon able to establish a link between them and illegal human experiments – all those years of Google-fu were finally becoming useful.

With a link established it was tie to go deeper and find out exactly what was going on at the clinic. An undercover team was dispatched after closure to bug the building for remote monitoring. And then silence. The agency ceased contact until Sunday when all agents abruptly received an email informing us that the alert level had been “raised to 3″. With urgency we made our way to our usual channels of communication (IRC) and began to converse about what could be happening, and there it was. In our game clients was an image coded in braille.

The image was surprisingly complex, containing not only the braille code, but a map that could be uncovered by applying various filters, and behind that were words which turned out to be street names. Some very intelligent deciphering later we had uncovered a restaurant in Portland called “The Fried Onion”.  Initial reconnaissance of the location yielded no results, but now as the restaurant opens for business, we have agents on route for a face to face with forces unknown.

Now we wait

_____________________________________________________________________________
Previewed with a promotional key from developer. Original post here:
http://criticalindiegamer.com/2015/06/a-weekend-with-the-black-watchmen-arg/

16717334.review:
Long story short, this isn't a game for you if you don't plan to give out your cell phone number, actual address, and from what I've researched, most of your time in order to experience all of the game's content.

If that [i]is[/i] something you're into, however, then this is probably going to be quite the experience.

The idea behind the game's mechanics is very interesting. It teaches you to think outside the box, analyze details carefully, and especially do your homework and deeper research into the subject in mind. For example, for one scenario, I had like ten tabs open just to research this one point. The sense of reward and accomplishment also in completing the hard task of figuring out the answer to an investigation is just too good.

And then, there comes the moment where you have to give out your information. Oh dear. In order to truly rise above the ranks and reach the top (so to speak,) you'll need to give out information such as your phone number, address, and to quote the game, "You may be contacted via phone calls, at all hours of the day or night, receive packages from the mail, and experience real world interactions with our assets in the field." Now, let me go ahead and say that this is not [i]required[/i] in order to experience the game. But if you expect to fully complete the game without giving this information out, good luck with that. I know someone who's actually been basically traumatized by this experience, but that's a story for another time that I wish to keep out of this. I understand that some are much more comfortable in giving out this information, and by all means that's A-OK. But personally, that is not something I'm doing any time soon. After all, this is the very nature of a game that's permanent alternate-reality.

To conclude, some of the game's puzzles (Being the few I've tried, hah,) are excellently thought out and I absolutely love them. The fact that I have to give my personal information out in order to get a full 100%, however, I don't. While I wouldn't personally recommend the game to people like myself, I would absolutely recommend it to others in a heartbeat. The experience doesn't look like any other. Its the type of game you would play if you were unemployed so you can say that you work for a private contractor who specializes in information collection [i]and[/i] go through the effort and time of an actual job.

16712371.review:
First of all, I'm recommending this game because *I* like it. That may seem obvious, but the reason I say it is that this game is most definetly not your "typical" game, and I can totally understand that a lot of people will hate it. If you don't like doing challenging puzzles where you have to look outside the game itself to find the answer, if you really don't like being part of the online "community" of a game, and if you don't have a certain tolerance for bashing your head against puzzles and skin-crawling creepyness in storylines, this game is not for you.

Awesome Thing #1: Permanent ARG
----------------------------------
The concept of a permanent ARG is really interesting. Basically the client is only part of the game, the *real* game is the overarching plot being run by puppetmasters (they are evil and sadistic and we love them). 

I'm crap at explaining this, but it's a really cool overal effect of a kind-of-real-world story going on. If you know what an ARG is and/or have participated in them (for example, the ones that were done around events/releases in The Secret World, which were run by some of the same people as this game) then you have some kind of familliarity with how it works. I dunno, google it I guess. 

Also, get used to googling things. And going off on tangents and chasing red herrings and having a really weird and sometimes frankly disturbing browser history.

Awesome Thing #2: The Community
--------------------------------------
I've been around this game and its community since the first kickstarter attempt, and first, let me say it's pretty hard to separate the two, and that's a good thing (usually). Unless you are some kind of puzzle solving supergenius, you *will* get stuck at some point, and many members of the community are totally willing to help without being too spoilery. There are also real world missions (yes, really, this has already happened in Alpha and in previous games) so it's actually requred for the community to find someone in a city where the clue leads to go pick up some dead drop somewhere. It is awesome when you get to be a part of something like this, even if it's just watching a webcam feed to see if/when an agent shows up...

Neutral Thing #1: Hard Puzzles
--------------------------------
The solo puzzles can be pretty hard (judging by some of the alpha and beta puzzles) but this version of the game starts you off pretty easy, and there's always the community to help. Check the forums, check IRC etc.

I really like the challenge of the puzzles. I like think-y games more than action games. This is a think-y game x 1000. I get that a lot of people won't like that, but there it is.

Sometimes the leaps of logic required can be a *liiittle* too far, in my opinion, but it's generally pretty fair, if hard.

Neutral Thing #2: Creepy Shit
-------------------------------
As for the creepyness, well. It just is. Some of the subjects in the puzzles involve illegal medical/psychological experiments on humans. One previous mission (may or may not be linked to in this game) involved tracking a serial killer. Some folks might find these things too disturbing, and I get that.

Me, I like spooky games. This one is spooky. If you don't like spooky, maybe not a good fit.

Not So Awesome Thing: Missing Out
--------------------------------------
My main complaint for the game is that partly because of my own bad timing/luck I've missed a bunch of the cool things that happened during testing. You really need to keep up with the game and be connected with the community (which may not be convenient for a lot of people, myself included some of the time) or you can miss things. Which leads to being confused as to what the bleep is going on when you try and jump back in to chat/forums, and some dissapointment at missing the coolness that went on while you were away...

Other than that though, this gets a thumbs up from me. I'm really excited to see where this game goes, and I hope it gets extended for more than one season. And that we don't get too many (fictional!) agents killed.

...And that I get kidnapped.

Look, you need to read this. You don't know what you're going to get into here.
The first few weeks I was fine. Just testing a beta client. 
I got to know some guys, chatted it up in irc. Normal stuff. Mailing teeth to the NSA.
Well then I noticed something was up.

The mailman comes each day at 2pm. Always on time. Until he didn't
He started arriving a little earlier everyday. 1:47, 1:43, 1:40. At first I thought nothing was wrong. Maybe the normal guy was out sick or on vacation. But the pattern. I can see all the hidden patterns now thanks to my time with the Black Watchmen. The government is on to me, they know what I'm doing at 4 in the morning. And they are using who I trust most, the man who delivers my Amazon packages, because I'm a cheap ass and get the slow shipping. I don't know how much time is left, but I've found the truth and the government knows. 

Now it's me or the mailman. I will not be silenced.
